item.title: Starmer Becomes U.K. Prime Minister After Labour Party Landslide
item.description: Labour’s resounding election victory ended 14 years of Conservative government. But a fragmented vote and low turnout pointed to a deeply unhappy Britain.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times

item.title: New Popular Front Scored Big in France’s Vote. Who Are Its Members?
item.description: Parties on the left were so fractious, they broke up their alliance months ago, but the possibility of a government controlled by the far right drew them back together.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Olivier Faure, left, and other left-wing coalition members waving during an open-air legislative election campaign meeting in the Paris suburbs in June.

item.title: Hurricane Beryl Bears Down on the Yucatán Peninsula
item.description: The storm, now a Category 2, has lost some power since slamming Jamaica and Grenada this week. A hurricane warning is in effect for the coast of the Yucatán Peninsula.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Labour Won a U.K. Landslide. Why Doesn’t It Feel Like That?
item.description: Keir Starmer’s party won a huge majority in parliament. But the new prime minister faces a fractious and volatile public.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The new Prime Minister, Keir Starmer, speaking outside 10 Downing Street on Friday.

item.title: Vatican Excommunicates Its Former Ambassador to the U.S.
item.description: Archbishop Carlo Maria Viganò, who was informed of his excommunication on Friday, has long been a vocal critic of Pope Francis.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Archbishop Carlo Maria Viganò speaking at a “Walk for Life” rally by abortion opponents in San Francisco in 2015.

item.title: Five Takeaways From the U.K. General Election
item.description: The Labour Party won a resounding victory over the Conservatives, but smaller parties, including the populist Reform, did better than expected.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Reacting to election results at a watch party in a London pub on Thursday.

item.title: Kazakh Journalist’s Killing Sends Chill Through Exiles in Ukraine
item.description: Aidos Sadykov, an opposition activist whose YouTube channel often criticizes Kazakhstan’s government, was shot in Ukraine, where he was living in exile.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners carrying the body of Aidos Sadykov, an opposition activist and journalist from Kazakhstan, to be buried on Friday.

item.title: Brazil Police Accuse Bolsonaro of Embezzling Saudi Jewels
item.description: Brazil’s former president, Jair Bolsonaro, may soon face criminal charges for stealing gifts he received from foreign leaders.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jair Bolsonaro, the former Brazilian president, at a political rally in February in São Paulo.

item.title: Gaza Cease-Fire Talks Revive After Weeks of Deadlock
item.description: The negotiations had been stalled for weeks until Hamas announced on Wednesday that it had exchanged some ideas with mediators on a new way forward.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: An Israeli tank near the border with Gaza, on Thursday.

item.title: Mount Etna Erupts, Spewing Lava and Clouds of Ash 15,000 Feet Into the Air
item.description: Clouds of ash went nearly 15,000 feet into the air, and the airport in Catania, Sicily, was forced to shut down because the runway was unusable.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola

item.title: Iran Voters Face Stark Choice in Competitive Presidential Runoff
item.description: For the first time in years, the outcome is difficult to predict, and could be decided by how many people end their boycotts and participate in the vote.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Casting votes at a religious institute in the second round of presidential election in Tehran on Friday.

item.title: Iran’s Presidential Candidates: Who Are They?
item.description: Two candidates face off in Iran’s runoff election on Friday after neither secured enough votes to win in the first round. Here’s what you need to know about their positions and background.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Masoud Pezeshkian, left, and Saeed Jalili, right, on a big screen during the last presidential debate in Tehran, on Tuesday.

item.title: Hungary’s Viktor Orban Travels to Russia for Meeting With Vladimir Putin
item.description: Days after a trip to Ukraine, the Hungarian leader arrived in Moscow for a visit, but E.U. officials made clear that he was not there on behalf of the bloc.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Valeriy Sharifulin/Sputnik, via, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary and President Vladimir Putin of Russia in Moscow on Friday, in a photo released by Russian state media.

item.title: Japan Finally Phases Out Floppy Disks
item.description: One of the world’s most technologically advanced nations has held on to some of the most outmoded devices.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon, Hisako Ueno and Kiuko Notoya
item.media:description: This now-obsolete format, a magnetic disk encased in a plastic, has not been manufactured for 13 years.

item.title: Andrew Tate Is Allowed to Leave Romania in Latest Court Decision
item.description: The court in Bucharest ruled that Mr. Tate and his brother, who are facing human trafficking and rape charges, must remain in the European Union as they await trial, his lawyer said.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall
item.media:description: Andrew Tate, a social media influencer, said he was “free” to leave Romania in a video posted on social media on Friday. His lawyer confirmed that a court in Bucharest ruled that he could travel within the European Union while awaiting trial.

item.title: Reform U.K.’s Success Is Latest Sign of Strength for Europe’s Far Right
item.description: The insurgent anti-immigration party led by Nigel Farage secured around 14 percent of the vote in Britain’s general election, though it has won only five parliamentary seats.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Nigel Farage celebrating in Clacton-on-Sea, England, early Friday.

item.title: Count Binface and Elmo Provided a Bit of Comic Relief in Britain’s Elections
item.description: As has long been the tradition in Britain, the elections included various joke candidates who often run against prominent politicians.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Elmo kept smiling through his election loss on Thursday night.

item.title: Who Is Angela Rayner, Britain’s Deputy Prime Minister?
item.description: While politics in Britain have traditionally been dominated by the country’s elites, Ms. Rayner has taken a less traditional route to the top.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Angela Rayner arriving at 10 Downing Street on Friday.

item.title: Who Is David Lammy, Britain’s New Foreign Secretary?
item.description: Mr. Lammy has deep ties to the United States and campaigned for former President Barack Obama.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Lammy in the North London town of Tottenham in April.

item.title: Labour Wins Back the Trust of Jewish Voters
item.description: Keir Starmer had made rooting out antisemitism from the Labour Party’s ranks a goal of his leadership.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Keir Starmer, who describes himself as an atheist, is married to Victoria Starmer, who comes from a Jewish family.

item.title: Who Is Rachel Reeves, the Woman Taking the Helm of the U.K.’s Economy?
item.description: As the newly named chancellor of the Exchequer, she is taking on the tough job of boosting Britain’s productivity growth and of reviving struggling public services.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Stefan Rousseau/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Rachel Reeves, the new chancellor of the Exchequer, right, with Keir Starmer, the new prime minister, last month.

item.title: Sometimes It Is the Coach’s Fault
item.description: The U.S. collapsed under the weight of expectations at the Copa América. Its next move could determine if there is a repeat, or a revival, at the 2026 World Cup.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.category: United States Men's National Soccer Team
item.media:description: The United States tumbled out of the Copa América and right into a self-inflicted crisis.

item.title: The Greens Take a Bite of Labour’s Vote Share
item.description: The left-leaning Green Party, which is particularly popular with people under 30, took seven percent of the vote and will now have four lawmakers in Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:description: Green Party co-leaders Carla Denyer, left, and Adrian Ramsay, at their election manifesto launch in Hove, England, in June.

item.title: Keir Starmer Vows ‘National Renewal’ in First Speech as UK Prime Minister
item.description: The Labour leader promised in a speech in Downing Street to restore Britain’s faith in politics and public service.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times

item.title: U.K. Liberal Democrats Make Big Election Gains
item.description: The small centrist party campaigned on improving health and social care. Its leader, Ed Davey, wooed voters with publicity stunts and personal appeals.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Ed Davey, leader of the Liberal Democrat party, speaking in Whittlesford, England, in May.

item.title: Britain’s New Prime Minister Had Just Hours to Prepare
item.description: A new U.S. president usually has a two-month window to prepare to move into the White House. Freshly elected British prime ministers move into Downing Street much more swiftly.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: The famed address has been home to prime ministers since 1735. And it’s much larger than it seems from the street.

item.title: Rishi Sunak Defends Record in Last Speech as Prime Minister
item.description: In brief remarks in Downing Street, he apologized to Britain for his failings and accepted responsibility for his party’s stinging election defeat.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle

item.title: Labour Loses Votes in Muslim Areas Over Its Gaza Policy
item.description: Many British Muslims and other voters have demanded that party leaders more vocally condemn the rising death toll and deepening humanitarian crisis in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: A protest in London last month calling for an end to the war in Gaza.

item.title: UK Election Turnout Set to Be Lowest in Over 20 Years
item.description: Voter participation was estimated at 60 percent — below that in every recent election except 2001, another widely anticipated landslide.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside a polling station in Portsmouth, England, on Thursday.

item.title: Trump Advisers Call for U.S. Nuclear Weapons Testing if He Is Elected
item.description: A former national security adviser says Washington “must test new nuclear weapons for reliability and safety in the real world,” while critics say the move could incite a global arms race that heightens the risk of war.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: A drop test of a B61 nuclear bomb. An aide to Mr. Trump’s former national security adviser said a redesign of this type of bomb, the B61-13, announced in October, was in need of explosive testing.

item.title: UK Election: What Happens Next
item.description: The transition of power in Britain is a matter of hours, not months.
item.dc:creator: Peter Robins
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Journalists gathering outside Downing Street in London, where Rishi Sunak was expected to give his last speech as prime minister at 10:30 a.m. local time.

item.title: How the Labour Party Wants to Change the UK Economy
item.description: With Britain’s productivity and wages stalled for the past decade and a half, the winning party in the general election faces a tall order.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Portsmouth, England, on Wednesday. The Labour Party has said it would try to boost growth all over Britain.

item.title: Australian Author’s Novel-Turned-Film Goes Global
item.description: Lily Brett’s delight is bittersweet as “Too Many Men,” her story about traveling with her father, becomes a movie he did not live to see.
item.dc:creator: Julia Bergin
item.media:credit: Sebastian Gollnow/picture alliance, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Lena Dunham, left, and Stephen Fry, the stars of “Treasure,” with the film’s director, Julia von Heinz, at the 74th Berlin International Film Festival in February.

item.title: Liz Truss Caps List of High-Profile Conservative Seat Losses
item.description: Ms. Truss, who was forced out as prime minister after 49 chaotic days, lost by 630 votes in a district she previously held by more than 26,000.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Jacob King/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Liz Truss, the former prime minister, leaving after she lost her seat during the count in King’s Lynn, England, on Friday.

item.title: Man Who Stabbed South Korea’s Opposition Leader Is Sentenced to 15 Years
item.description: The attack on Lee Jae-myung in January raised alarms about South Korea’s political polarization. His assailant was convicted of attempted murder.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Lee Jae-myung in January after being discharged from a Seoul hospital, eight days after he was stabbed.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: A landslide victory for Labour.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Results of an exit poll are projected onto the BBC Broadcasting House in London on Thursday night.

item.title: Cristiano Ronaldo, Euro 2024 and the Problem With Too Much Fame
item.description: The soccer superstar’s trip to Euro 2024 has been marked by pitch invaders and uninspiring performances. As fans try to get close, his team can’t seem to let go.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith and Tariq Panja
item.media:description: Cristiano Ronaldo’s Euro 2024 statistics: selfie-seeking fans (many), goals (zero), frustration (mounting).

item.title: Growing Economic Anxiety and Inequality Fuels Unrest Worldwide
item.description: Economic turmoil is spreading across the globe, and the response has been protests, attempted coups and elections of far-right politicians.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen and Jack Nicas
item.media:description: Protests in Bolivia in June. Residents have lined up for gas because of shortages and a military general led a failed coup attempt.

item.title: Malaria Vaccine Rollout to Africa Is a Cautionary Tale
item.description: After years of delay, millions of malaria vaccines are being supplied to children in Africa. Tens of thousands died waiting.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen

item.title: Rishi Sunak Hangs On to His Seat in Parliament
item.description: The prime minister will remain a lawmaker after a close race in his North Yorkshire constituency.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Britain’s Prime Minister Rishi Sunak at 10 Downing Street last year.

item.title: Nigel Farage, Right-Wing Disrupter, Elected to Parliament for the First Time
item.description: His upstart party, Reform U.K., was projected to win four seats, a strong showing, according to a nationwide exit poll.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nigel Farage, leader of the Reform party, greeting locals in Clacton-on-Sea, England, last month.

item.title: Jeremy Corbyn Wins Election Against Labour, Party He Once Led
item.description: The victory was vindication for Mr. Corbyn, who was running for the first time against the Labour party.
item.dc:creator: Joel Petterson
item.media:description: Britain’s former Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn after submitting his nomination papers to officially stand as an independent candidate for the general election in Islington North, in June.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Labour Projected to Win U.K. Election
item.description: Plus, Iran heads to the polls.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: If confirmed, it would be one of the worst defeats in the Conservative Party’s history.

item.title: Keir Starmer Is Britain’s New Prime Minister
item.description: The 61-year-old former human rights lawyer lacks the star power of some of his predecessors but led a remarkable turnaround for the Labour Party.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle, Mark Landler and Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Stefan Rousseau/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Keir Starmer, leader of the Labour Party, in Whitland, Wales, on Wednesday.

item.title: As Beryl Moves On, Ravaged Islands Assess the Devastation
item.description: The hurricane caused destruction across the Caribbean, but some were relieved that it hadn’t been worse.
item.dc:creator: Jovan Johnson, Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Eric Nagourney
item.media:description: A beach was closed in Cancún, a resort destination on the Yucatán Peninsula of Mexico as Hurricane Beryl came closer on Thursday.

item.title: Russia Arrests Top Military Officer, Artyom Gorodilov, on Corruption Charges
item.description: Col. Artyom Gorodilov, who oversaw forces occupying the Ukrainian city where a massacre took place, was arrested and accused of large-scale fraud.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destroyed civilian cars littered a main road leading out of Bucha, Ukraine, in April 2022. The city was occupied by Russian troops in the early days of the war.

item.title: Who Are the Key Players in the UK Election?
item.description: Millions cast ballots for parliamentary seats on Thursday. The party that wins the most seats usually forms Britain’s next government, and that party’s leader becomes prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Esther Bintliff and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: The Parliament in London on Thursday. The political party that wins the most seats on Thursday usually forms Britain’s next government, and that party’s leader also becomes prime minister.

item.title: UK Election Night: When to Expect Results
item.description: Almost every district is expected to declare a winner by 7 a.m. local time. A clear opposition victory would result in a quick transition of power.
item.dc:creator: Peter Robins
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside a polling station in Saffron Walden, England, on Thursday.

item.title: Justice Department Opens Criminal Investigation in Chinese Doping Case
item.description: The move escalates a fight with China and world antidoping officials, and will cast a shadow over the Paris Olympics.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Schmidt and Tariq Panja
item.media:description: China’s swimming team for the Paris Olympics includes 11 athletes who have previously tested positive for banned substances.

item.title: Greece’s Six-Day Workweek: What to Know
item.description: The country, which already has the European Union’s longest average workweek, wants to add another day in some cases, bucking a growing business trend.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis and Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Greek workers demonstrated outside the Finance Ministry in Athens in May during a strike to protest low wages amid high living costs.

item.title: Why More French Youth Are Voting for the Far Right
item.description: Most young people in France usually don’t vote or they back the left. That is still true, but support has surged for the far right, whose openly racist past can feel to them like ancient history.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden, Aida Alami and Dmitry Kostyukov
item.media:description: Young National Rally supporters distributing election leaflets in a Paris suburb.

item.title: This English Naval City Is a Bellwether Seat. How Do Voters Feel?
item.description: As voters cast their ballots in a pivotal election, many in the southern English city of Portsmouth expressed disillusionment over what they see as national and local decline.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voters at a polling station in Portsmouth, England, on Thursday morning.

item.title: First Black African-Born Member of German Parliament Won’t Seek Re-election
item.description: Karamba Diaby, whose 2013 victory was considered a win for equality, said he wanted more time with his family. But he has also spoken of the death threats he has received.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Maslin Nir
item.media:description: Karamba Diaby in the German Parliament in December. Bullets were fired through the window of his district office in 2020, and the office was a target of arson last year.

item.title: Israeli Leaders to Discuss Hamas Response on Cease-Fire Proposal
item.description: A senior White House official called progress in talks with Hamas “a breakthrough,” while Israel was more restrained, and both said major obstacles to a truce remained.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Michael D. Shear and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Debris covered streets in Khan Younis, in the southern Gaza Strip, on Thursday.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Sentences Producer to 13 Years in Prison Over Netflix Show
item.description: In a video plea for help, Abdulaziz Almuzaini — a dual Saudi-American citizen — described how the authorities had accused him of promoting extremism through a cartoon franchise.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:credit: Daniele Venturelli/Getty Images for The Red Sea International Film Festival
item.media:description: Abdulaziz Almuzaini at a movie festival in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, in November.

item.title: Fight Over Seabed Agency Leadership Turns Nasty
item.description: An election over the future of a United Nations-affiliated organization could determine whether the Pacific Ocean floor will soon be mined for metals used in electric vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton
item.media:description: Kiribati, a tiny island in the Pacific Ocean, is playing a critical role in the election of the next secretary general of the International Seabed Authority.

item.title: On Canada’s Coastal Islands, a Win for Indigenous Rights
item.description: British Columbia recognized the Haida’s aboriginal title to their islands decades after the Indigenous group launched a battle on the ground and in the courts.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Amber Bracken
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken forThe New York Times
